#Text=Santa
#Text=Cruz ( department , Bolivia )
#Text=Santa Cruz department is located in Tropical Lowlands of Bolivia , and is the largest in the country .
#Text=Cities
#Text=– The capital .
#Text=–
#Text=A little and beautiful colonial town , 2.5 hr away from Santa Cruz city with tropical climate and filled with culture .
#Text=Enjoy the fish there served on a plate , which seems to be popular .
#Text=– Start of the river towards Trinidad .
#Text=–
#Text=A little town 40 min away from Santa Cruz , extremely old and filled with culture .
#Text=Features an interesting sunday market .
#Text=Also , in the treetops of the plaza you can find a handful of just sitting around and barely moving sloths , if you are able to spot them — if not , ask the locals . ( Bring a zoom camera ! )
#Text=/ Puerto Quijarro – On the border with Brazil .
#Text=– 2.5 hr east of Santa Cruz with heavenly climate , El Fuerte and lots of other things .
#Text=Other destinations
#Text=Noel Kempff National Park .
#Text=There are two sides to the park , the north , which is more regarding waterfalls , and the south , which concentrates more on the beautiful mountains ranges .
#Text=Amboró National Park .
#Text=There are two sides to this park , the north , which is more regarding jungle and monkeys , and the south , which concentrates more on the beautiful volcano mountains .
#Text=Kaa Iya National Park .
#Text=Just 6 hours from Santa Cruz city , this is one of the world 's best places to see jaguars , tapirs and pumas .
#Text=It 's an extremely remote National Park .
#Text=Use of satellite Phone , 4WD and special permits are required to enter this park .
#Text=Lomas de Arena .
#Text=A 14,000-hectare protected area which is a spectacular Natural Desert which is surrounded by tropical forests .
#Text=It 's an excellent place for bird watching as well as sand boarding , trekking and photography .
#Text=Pantanal Boliviano .
#Text=A huge nature reserve that covers parts of Bolivia , Paraguay and Brazil .
#Text=A wide range of land and water animals live here , even deer .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Santa Cruz is in the lowlands at the east of the country .

#Text=This department concentrates 27 % of the country´s population , several of the major universities of Bolivia and it 's responds for over 30 % of the country wealth production , forty something percent of the national taxes .
#Text=It´s population is variate , some 40 % of it´s inhabitants were born elsewhere ( mainly in the rest of the Bolivian departments ) .

#Text=They seek what more of what they call " Autonomia " which means autonomy and intends to separate more functions from the central government in a way similar to Spain government system , more independent and locally managed .

#Text=In this country like many others of South America , citizens have to support the burden of time and cost of doing most bureaucratic administrative procedures from far away from La Paz in a corrupt and inefficient system .
#Text=History
#Text=When the Spaniards originally arrived to these lands , they came from Paraguay and Argentina .
#Text=The local indigenous peoples came from two lines , or as they are called Tupi-Guarani .
#Text=The first , the Tupi originally came from the Caribbean through the Amazon jungle down to these latitudes .
#Text=The Guarani´s came here down the Atlantic coast through what today is Brazil and Argentina , and upriver from there .
#Text=They were the original humans in this region and they had gone well into the lower Andes .

#Text=Nowadays it is only possible to find possible reminders of the onetime greatness of this two cultures in Moxos ( Beni department ) or in southern Bolivia or northern Argentina and it requires investigation because little is known and they are not part of touristic routes .
#Text=The blend of these three and other latecomers are the local native population , they call themselves " Camba or Cambas " .
#Text=These people are mostly of peasant origin that dedicated itself to farming related activities , this still is the main department´s activity .
#Text=Today , with the migrations of this last quarter century these people are maybe around one half of the local population .
#Text=One interesting characteristic of this region is that most of the more recently arrived inhabitants have integrated fairly well .
#Text=Obviously there are exceptions to this .
#Text=Being a land with so many bloods , sympathy and tolerance to outsiders is fairly high by any standard .

#Text=One interesting characteristic of the " Cruceños " or people from Santa Cruz is that apparently they prefer not having to work in public services ( Government , armed forces , police , diplomatic services , church , others ) and as someone said , they don´t migrate , they just move around .
#Text=This probably explains why of some 100 Bolivian presidents in almost two centuries , only three were from Santa Cruz department .
#Text=And all three were military , which is a factor that changes people through doctrines embedded into its members during their careers .
#Text=One very interesting testimony of this history can be downloaded ( in Spanish for free ) from the United Nations Development Programme ( UNDP ) .
#Text=The document is called Informe de Desarrollo Humano de Santa Cruz and the first chapter relates the history of Santa Cruz in this last half of the 20th century .
#Text=By bus
#Text=Mostly Santa Cruz city will be your transfer hub .
#Text=If you are coming in from Argentina or Paraguay , you will have to come in by highway ( bus or other ) , information is available in any major city´s bus station .
#Text=By plane
#Text=Direct airplane flights are available to and from Santa Cruz city 's Viru Viru International Airport ( VVI ) and El Trompillo Airport ( SRZ ) .
#Text=By train
#Text=If you are coming from Brazil , you can take the Tren de la Muerte or Death Train .

#Text=( The name does not reflect the degree of safety of the train , but rather how many people died building the railroad along this route . ) So , if you are in Corumbá , a Brazilian border city , you just have to cross the frontier , take a taxi to the train station in Bolivia ( they do n't accept Brazilian taxi drivers there ) and go to the train station .
#Text=Depending on the class of train you want to take , it will take a different time to get to Santa Cruz city .
#Text=Also , trains are occasionally available from the Argentine border .
#Text=By boat
#Text=You can get in but slow and authentic cargo boat from the Beni department — read there for more details .
